required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Communication Strategy to PROMOTE HPV Vaccination in Pharmacies: PROMOTE Study
clinical_study.official_title: Pharmacy Multimodal Communication Strategy to Promote HPV Vaccination

brief_summary.textblock: This trial investigates how a communication strategy works in increasing human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccines in community pharmacies among adolescents. Although pharmacies are vaccine providers, low vaccination rates are persistent as a result of low awareness of pharmacy services and poor engagement by pharmacy staff with adolescents about vaccines. The purpose of this study is to test a communication strategy that identifies vaccine-eligible children and teaches pharmacy staff how to effectively communicate with them about HPV vaccination in order to increase HPV vaccination rates.

detailed_description.textblock:
OUTLINE:
AIM 1: Participants participate in a semi-structured interview in-person or via phone over 90 minutes about barriers/facilitators of HPV vaccination in pharmacies. Pharmacies of which the pharmacy staff participants work undergo an environmental scan to characterize the pharmacy's environment, vaccination workflow, and team dynamics.
AIM 2: Participants provide feedback on survey questions via cognitive testing. Pharmacy staff complete an online survey over 10-15 minutes to assess the acceptability, appropriateness, and feasibility of providing HPV vaccination to children aged 9-17 in their pharmacies. Pharmacy staff then attend communication training sessions, and then undergo a communication strategy intervention over no more than 120 minutes consisting of identifying vaccine-eligible children and recommending HPV and other vaccines. Pharmacy staff employ the new communication strategy in their pharmacy over 6 months, and then complete an online survey over 10-15 minutes.

clinical_study.why_stopped: Study is currently on hold for recruitment for Aim 2.

primary_outcome.measure: Behavioral barriers to human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccination in pharmacies
primary_outcome.description: Assess experiences and perceptions among parents and pharmacy staff on the challenges of obtaining/delivering HPV vaccination in pharmacies. Obtain feedback on how the communication strategy being tested address barriers to obtaining/delivering HPV vaccination in pharmacies. Assessments will be done through semi-structured interviews informed by the Theoretical Domains Framework. Qualitative data will be analyzed using framework-guided rapid analyses

primary_outcome.measure: Behavioral facilitators to human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccination in pharmacies
primary_outcome.description: Assess experiences and perceptions among parents and pharmacy staff on how pharmacies support, promote, and increase access and opportunities for HPV vaccination for children. Obtain feedback on how the communication strategy being tested can help improve obtaining/delivering HPV vaccination in pharmacies. Assessments will be done through semi-structured interviews informed by the Theoretical Domains Framework. Qualitative data will be analyzed using framework-guided rapid analyses

primary_outcome.measure: Acceptability of providing HPV vaccination to children and of the proposed communication strategy to support HPV vaccination
primary_outcome.description: Will use adapted, validated, four-item survey measure to assess pharmacy staff's report of the acceptability of providing HPV vaccination to children and of the communication strategy to support HPV vaccination.

primary_outcome.measure: Appropriateness of providing HPV vaccination to children and of the proposed communication strategy to support HPV vaccination
primary_outcome.description: Will use adapted, validated, four-item survey measure to assess pharmacy staff's report of the appropriateness of providing HPV vaccination to children and of the communication strategy to support HPV vaccination.

primary_outcome.measure: Feasibility of providing HPV vaccination to children and of the proposed communication strategy to support HPV vaccination
primary_outcome.description: Will use adapted, validated, four-item survey measure to assess pharmacy staff's report of the feasibility of providing HPV vaccination to children and of the communication strategy to support HPV vaccination.
Will use adapted, validated survey measures to assess pharmacy staff's report of the self-efficacy (i.e., confidence in their ability) to provide HPV vaccination.
Will conduct audits of the pharmacy electronic records to assess adoption of HPV vaccination, measured as the average HPV vaccination rate per pharmacist at each pharmacy.

Will assess the impact of the communication strategy on adoption of other adolescent vaccines using pre-post data analysis methods like Wilcoxon signed-rank test or other nonparametric tests appropriate for small sample statistics.

arm_group.description: Participants participate in a semi-structured interview in-person or via phone over 90 minutes about barriers/facilitators of HPV vaccination in pharmacies. Pharmacies of which the pharmacy staff participants work undergo an environmental scan to characterize the pharmacy's environment, vaccination workflow, and team dynamics.

Participants provide feedback on survey questions via cognitive testing. Pharmacy staff complete an online survey over 10-15 minutes to assess the acceptability, appropriateness, and feasibility of providing HPV vaccination to children aged 9-17 in their pharmacies. Pharmacy staff then attend communication training sessions, and then undergo a communication strategy intervention over no more than 120 minutes consisting of identifying vaccine-eligible children and recommending HPV and other vaccines. Pharmacy staff employ the new communication strategy in their pharmacy over 6 months, and then complete an online survey over 10-15 minutes.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- AIM 1 (PARENTS/GUARDIANS): Individuals with children between the ages of 9-17 in their care who are English speakers, live in Washington state, and have access to a telephone or computer with internet access (up to 12 parents)
- AIM 1 (PHARMACY STAFF): Employed at a Western Washington Bartell Drugs pharmacy sites and have access to a telephone or computer with internet access
- AIM 2: Pharmacy staff employed at a participating Western Washington pharmacy sites who speak English and have access to a computer with internet access
Exclusion Criteria:
- AIM 1 (PARENTS/GUARDIANS): Those who object to having their interview audio recorded
- AIM 1 (PHARMACY STAFF): Floaters/per diem. Those who object to having their interview audio recorded

overall_official.affiliation: Fred Hutch/University of Washington Cancer Consortium

facility.name: Fred Hutch/University of Washington Cancer Consortium
